question: Question 1 Suppose that [latex]L_1[/latex] is a regular language and [latex]L_2[/latex] is a context-free language. Which one of the following languages is NOT necessarily context-free?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]L_1\cap L_2[/latex]
options.B: [latex]L_1\cdot L_2[/latex]
options.C: [latex]L_1 - L_2[/latex]
options.D: [latex]L_1\cup L_2[/latex]

question: Question 2 Let P be an array containing n integers. Let t be the lowest upper bound on the number of comparisons of the array elements, required to find the minimum and maximum values in an arbitrary array of n elements. Which one of the following choices is correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]t \gt 2n-2[/latex]
options.B: [latex]t \gt 3\lceil \frac{n}{2}\rceil \text{ and } t\leq 2n-2[/latex]
options.C: [latex]t \gt n \text{ and } t\leq 3\lceil \frac{n}{2}\rceil[/latex]
options.D: [latex]t \gt \lceil \log_2(n)\rceil \text{ and } t\leq n[/latex]

question: Question 3 Consider the following three functions. [latex]f_1=10^n\; f_2=n^{\log n}\;f_3=n^{\sqrt {n}}[/latex] Which one of the following options arranges the functions in the increasing order of asymptotic growth rate?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]f_3, f_2, f_1[/latex]
options.B: [latex]f_2, f_1, f_3[/latex]
options.C: [latex]f_1, f_2, f_3[/latex]
options.D: [latex]f_2, f_3, f_1[/latex]

question: Question 26 Consider the following grammar (that admits a series of declarations, followed by expressions) and the associated syntax directed translation (SDT) actions, given as pseudo-code [latex]\begin{array}{lll} P & \rightarrow & D^* E^* \\ D & \rightarrow & \textsf{int ID} \{ \text{record that } \textsf{ID.} \text{lexeme is of type} \textsf{ int\}} \\ D & \rightarrow & \textsf{bool ID} \{ \text{record that } \textsf{ID.} \text{lexeme is of type} \textsf{ bool\}} \\ E& \rightarrow & E_1 +E_2 \{ \text{check that } E_1. \text{type}=E_2. \text{type} = \textsf{int}; \text{set } E.\text{type }:= \textsf{int} \} \\ E & \rightarrow & !E_1 \{ \text{check that } E_1. \text{type} = \textsf{bool}; \text{ set } E.\text{type} := \textsf{bool} \} \\ E & \rightarrow & \textsf{ID} \{ \text{set } E. \text{type } := \textsf{int} \} \end{array}[/latex] With respect to the above grammar, which one of the following choices is correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The actions can be used to correctly type-check any syntactically correct program
options.B: The actions can be used to type-check syntactically correct integer variable declarations and integer expressions
options.C: The actions can be used to type-check syntactically correct boolean variable declarations and boolean expressions.
options.D: The actions will lead to an infinite loop

question: Question 27 The following relation records the age of 500 employees of a company, where empNo ( indicating the employee number) is the key: [latex]empAge(\underline{empNo},age)[/latex] Consider the following relational algebra expression: [latex]\Pi_{empNo}(empAge \Join_{(age > age1)} \rho_{empNo1,age1}(empAge))[/latex] What does the above expression generate?

options.B: Employee numbers of only those employees whose age is more than the age of exactly one other employee
options.C: Employee numbers of all employees whose age is not the minimum
options.D: Employee numbers of all employees whose age is the minimum

question: Question 30 Consider the following recurrence relation. [latex]T\left ( n \right )=\left\{\begin{array} {lcl} T(n/2)+T(2n/5)+7n & \text{if} \; n > 0\\1 & \text{if}\; n=0 \end{array}\right.[/latex] Which one of the following options is correct?

question: Question 32 Let [latex]r_i(z)[/latex] and [latex]w_i(z)[/latex] denote read and write operations respectively on a data item [latex]z[/latex] by a transaction [latex]T_i[/latex]. Consider the following two schedules. [latex]S1: r_1(x)r_1(y)r_2(x)r_2(y)w_2(y)w_1(x)[/latex] [latex]S2: r_1(x)r_2(x)r_2(y)w_2(y)r_1(y)w_1(x)[/latex] Which one of the following options is correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: S1 is conflict serializable, and S2 is not conflict serializable
options.B: S1 is not conflict serializable, and S2 is conflict serializable
options.C: Both S1 and S2 are conflict serializable
options.D: Niether S1 nor S2 is conflict serializable

question: Question 33 Consider the relation [latex]R(P,Q,S,T,X,Y,Z,W)[/latex] with the following functional dependencies. [latex]PQ\rightarrow X;\quad P\rightarrow YX;\quad Q\rightarrow Y; \quad Y\rightarrow ZW[/latex] Consider the decomposition of the relation R into the constituent relations according to the following two decomposition schemes. [latex]D1:\quad R=[(P,QS,T);\;(P,T,X);\;(Q,Y);\;(Y,Z,W)][/latex] [latex]D2:\quad R=[(P,Q,S);\;(T,X);\;(Q,Y);\;(Y,Z,W)][/latex] Which one of the following options is correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: D1 is a lossless decomposition, but D2 is a lossy decomposition.
options.B: D1 is a lossy decomposition, but D2 is a lossless decomposition.
options.C: Both D1 and D2 are lossless decompositions.
options.D: Both D1 and D2 are lossy decompositions.

question: Question 34 Let G be a group of order 6, and H be a subgroup of G such that 1 < |H| < 6. Which one of the following options is correct?

options.A: Both G and H are always cyclic.
options.B: G may not be cyclic, but H is always cyclic.
options.C: G is always cyclic, but H may not be cyclic.
options.D: Both G and H may not be cyclic.

question: Question 35 Consider the two statements. S1: There exist random variables [latex]X[/latex] and [latex]Y[/latex] such that [latex]\left(\mathbb E[(X-\mathbb E(X))(Y-\mathbb E(Y))]\right)^2 > \textsf{Var}[X]\textsf{Var}[Y][/latex] S2: For all random variables [latex]X[/latex] and [latex]Y[/latex], [latex]\textsf{Cov}[X,Y]=\mathbb E \left[|X-\mathbb E[X]||Y-\mathbb E[Y]|\right ][/latex] Which one of the following choices is correct?

options.A: Both S1 and S2 are true.
options.B: S1 is true, but S2 is false.
options.C: S1 is false, but S2 is true.
options.D: Both S1 and S2 are false.

question: Question 36 Let [latex]G=(V,E)[/latex] be an undirected unweighted connected graph. The diameter of [latex]G[/latex] is defined as: [latex]diam(G)=\displaystyle \max_{u,v \in V} \{ \text{the length of shortest path between }u \text{ and }v \}[/latex] Let [latex]M[/latex] be the adjacency matrix of [latex]G[/latex]. Define graph [latex]G_2[/latex] on the same set of vertices with adjacency matrix [latex]N[/latex], where [latex]N_{ij}=\left\{\begin{array} {lcl} 1 &\text{if}\; M_{ij}>0 \text{ or } P_{ij}>0, \text{ where }P=M^2\\0 &\text{otherwise} \end{array}\right.[/latex] Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]diam(G_2)\leq \left \lceil diam(G)/2 \right \rceil[/latex]
options.B: [latex]\left \lceil diam(G)/2 \right \rceil \lt diam(G_2) \lt diam(G)[/latex]
options.C: [latex]diam(G_2) =diam(G)[/latex]
options.D: [latex]diam(G) \lt diam(G_2) \leq 2 \; diam(G)[/latex]

solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: The program will not compile successfully
options.B: The program will compile successfully and output 10 when executed
options.C: The program will compile successfully and output 8 when executed
options.D: The program will compile successfully and output 13 when executed

question: Question 39 For a Turing machine M, < M > denotes an encoding of M. Consider the following two languages. [latex]\begin{array}{ll} L1 = \{ \langle M \rangle \mid M \text{ takes more than } 2021 \text{ steps on all inputs} \} \\ L2 = \{ \langle M \rangle \mid M\text{ takes more than } 2021 \text{ steps on some input} \} \end{array}[/latex] Which one of the following options is correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: Both L1 and L2 are decidable.
options.B: L1 is decidable  and L2 is undecidable.
options.C: L1 is undecidable  and L2 is decidable.
options.D: Both L1 and L2 are undecidable.

question: Question 40 Define [latex]R_n[/latex] to be the maximum amount earned by cutting a rod of length n meters into one or more pieces of integer length and selling them. For [latex]i > 0[/latex], let [latex]p[i][/latex] denote the selling price of a rod whose length is [latex]i[/latex] meters. Consider the array of prices: [latex]\text{p}[1]=1,\text{p}[2]=5,\text{p}[3]=8,\text{p}[4]=9,\text{p}[5]=10,\text{p}[6]=17,\text{p}[7]=18[/latex] which of the following statements is/are correct about [latex]R_7[/latex]?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: [latex]R_7=18[/latex]
options.B: [latex]R_7=19[/latex]
options.C: [latex]R_7[/latex] is achieved by three different solutions.
options.D: [latex]R_7[/latex] cannot be achieved by a solution consisting of three pieces.

question: Question 41 An articulation point in a connected graph is a vertex such that removing the vertex and its incident edges disconnects the graph into two or more connected components. Let T be a DFS tree obtained by doing DFS in a connected undirected graph G. Which of the following options is/are correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: Root of T can never be an articulation point in G.
options.B: Root of T is an articulation point in G if and only if it has 2 or more children.
options.C: A leaf of T can be an articulation point in G.
options.D: If u is an articulation point in G such that x is an ancestor of u in T and y is a descendent of u in T, then all paths from x to y in G must pass through u.

question: Question 42 Consider the following Boolean expression. [latex]F=(X+Y+Z)(\overline X +Y)(\overline Y +Z)[/latex] Which of the following Boolean expressions is/are equivalent to [latex]\overline F[/latex] (complement of [latex]F[/latex])?

options.A: [latex](\overline X +\overline Y +\overline Z)(X+\overline Y)(Y+\overline Z)[/latex]
options.B: [latex]X\overline Y + \overline Z[/latex]
options.C: [latex](X+\overline Z)(\overline Y +\overline Z)[/latex]
options.D: [latex]X\overline Y +Y\overline Z + \bar  X \bar Y \bar Z[/latex]

question: Question 43 A relation [latex]R[/latex] is said to be circular if [latex]aRb[/latex] and [latex]bRc[/latex] together imply [latex]cRa[/latex]. Which of the following options is/are correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: If a relation S is reflexive and symmetric, then S is an equivalence relation.
options.B: If a relation S is circular and symmetric, then S is an equivalence relation.
options.C: If a relation S is reflexive and circular, then S is an equivalence relation.
options.D: If a relation S is transitive and circular, then S is an equivalence relation.

question: Question 44 A TCP server application is programmed to listen on port number P on host S. A TCP client is connected to the TCP server over the network. Consider that while the TCP connection was active, the server machine S crashed and rebooted. Assume that the client does not use the TCP keepalive timer. Which of the following behaviors is/are possible?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: If the client was waiting to receive a packet, it may wait indefinitely.
options.B: The TCP server application on S can listen on P after reboot.
options.C: If the client sends a packet after the server reboot, it will receive a RST segment.
options.D: If the client sends a packet after the server reboot, it will receive a FIN segment.

question: Question 45 Consider two hosts P and Q connected through a router R. The maximum transfer unit (MTU) value of the link between P and R is 1500 bytes, and between R and Q is 820 bytes. A TCP segment of size 1400 bytes was transferred from P to Q through R, with IP identification value as 0x1234. Assume that the IP header size is 20 bytes. Further, the packet is allowed to be fragmented, i.e., Don't Fragment (DF) flag in the IP header is not set by P. Which of the following statements is/are correct?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: Two fragments are created at R and the IP datagram size carrying the second fragment is 620 bytes.
options.B: If the second fragment is lost, R will resend the fragment with the IP identification value 0x1234.
options.C: If the second fragment is lost, P is required to resend the whole TCP segment.
options.D: TCP destination port can be determined by analysing only the second fragment.

options.A: The value of countercounter is 5 after all the threads successfully complete the execution of parop.

question: Question 47 Consider a dynamic hashing approach for 4-bit integer keys: 1. There is a main hash table of size 4. 2. The 2 least significant bits of a key is used to index into the main hash table. 3. Initially, the main hash table entries are empty. 4. Thereafter, when more keys are hashed into it, to resolve collisions, the set of all keys corresponding to a main hash table. entry is organized as a binary tree that grows on demand. 5. First, the 3rd least significant bit is used to divide the keys into left and right subtrees. 6. To resolve more collisions, each node of the binary tree is further sub-divided into left and right subtrees based on the 4th least significant bit. 7. A split is done only if it is needed, i.e., only when there is a collision. Consider the following state of the hash table. Which of the following sequences of key insertions can cause the above state of the hash table (assume the keys are in decimal notation)?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow
Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

question: Question 53 A five-stage pipeline has stage delays of 150, 120, 150, 160 and 140 nanoseconds. The registers that are used between the pipeline stages have a delay of 5 nanoseconds each. [latex]\begin{array}{llc} \textbf{Instruction} & \textbf{Semantics} & \textbf{Instruction Size} \text{ (bytes)} \\ \hline \text{MOV } R1, (5000) & R1 \leftarrow \text{MEMORY}[5000] & 4 \\ \hline \text{MOV } R2, (R3) & R2 \leftarrow \text{MEMORY}[R3] & 4 \\ \hline \text{ADD} R2, R1 & R2 \leftarrow R1 + R2 & 2 \\ \hline \text{MOV } (R3), R2 & \text{MEMORY}[R3] \leftarrow R2 & 4 \\ \hline \text{INC } R3 & R3 \leftarrow R3+1 & 2 \\ \hline \text{DEC } R1 & R1 \leftarrow R1-1 & 2 \\ \hline \text{BNZ } 1004 & \text{Branch if not zero to the} & 2 \\ & \text{given absolute address} \\ \hline \text{HALT} & \text{Stop} & 1 \\ \hline \end{array}[/latex] Assume that the content of the memory location 5000 is 10, and the content of the register [latex]R_3[/latex] is 3000.
